bibl.title: Letter, General Alexander Hamilton in New York to Colonel Anthony Walton White, 1789 April 29
bibl.note: Greer and Vinsinger Family Collection of American Revolutionary War Documents

General Alexander Hamilton wrote this letter to Colonel Anthony Walton White on April 29, 1789. In it, he says that White's friends are disappointed that they haven't got the votes they needed from Harlem. Hamilton offers his aid to White and looks forward to their meeting at the Plough & Harrow at ten o'clock.

div.p: Your friends are somewhat disappointed, that there are no notes or very few from Harlem. We think it of much importance, that operation should be made, and you will much oblige us as well as serve the cause by lending your aid. Tommorow, it is presumed, curiousity may bring a considerable number to love town _ Here us It will be well worth attention to endeavour to give them a right direction. We shall with great pleasure see you at the head of a good column. at the Plough & Harrow at half past eleven ten o'clock
